comments.author: Crystine
comments.content: This is our families favorite soup! We just add way less hot chilis and use our own beans, dry corn, tomatoes and spices. Perfect in all ways and our child has a very selective palette!

comments.author: Crystine
comments.content: We try to be positive...I meant to write, "discerning"!

comments.author: Crystal
comments.content: I've been a vegetarian for 8 years now and this is the best pozole recipe I've encountered! I've missed it all this time! I like to use black beans instead of pinto and I've never had cheese with pozole.

comments.author: maria espinoza
comments.content:
I made a big pot of this for my ..."housemates".. they who tasted it, ate nearly the whole pot full!! Even the kids liked it! .. the remaining broth I used in place of the water when making rice, and then I added the remaining veggies and beans... it was good! lots of hot sauce, sour cream, and cole slaw!! yummy!! 

I bought more ingredients to make another pot full, but this time just for me!!

comments.author: Papalo
comments.content:
No pork, no problem!

It all depends what you mean by traditional…pork, and all farm animals, were introduced to the Americas at contact.  Posole is way older than that; it beggars belief that it was not made with whatever was available, vegetables in other words, with a flavoring of hunted meat if there was any.

comments.author: Mandarina
comments.content: According to wikipedia, posole was originally made by the Aztecs as a sort of communion-like dish for the whole community to eat together during special rituals, but was cooked with human meat from a sacrifice!  So I'm very happy to be enjoying a vegetarian and human-free version of this soup. Thanks for a great recipe.  :)

comments.author: Ryan Moulton
comments.content: Is this seriously calling for a tablespoon of oregano? I put in a tablespoon of powdered oregano, and all I can taste is the oregano. I don't particularly like oregano, so this is a bit of a bummer.

comments.author: Kathryn Brown
comments.content: I love this recipe!  And I love the book.  The photos are amazing!

comments.author: val
comments.content:
@Ryan, did you use Mexican oregano (crushed leaves, not powdered, which was maybe too much)? I used the full amount and I even had it in the beans I used, and it imparts a smoky flavor.
This is a seriously fantastic soup!
